Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: Type A: Development of Plasmofluidic Microscopy (PFM) for High-Sensitivity, High-Throughput Single-Molecule Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to The Pennsylvania State University to develop integrated plasmofluidic microscopy (PFM) that can conduct high-throughput, high-sensitivity single-molecule studies in a simple, compact, cost-effective, user-friendly format. With its unprecedented ability to achieve high sensitivity and high throughput simultaneously while using a relatively simple, low-cost format, the proposed PFM has the potential to transform the field of single-molecule studies and accelerate discoveries in many disciplines in biology, biochemistry, and medicine. This technology would be expected to have numerous diverse applications with immediate, positive implications. Examples include the study of molecular dynamics far from equilibrium, the characterization of molecular properties such as protein conformational changes and folding, or the investigation of protein-protein or protein-DNA interaction kinetics and dynamics. The proposed PFM will be disseminated through 1) recording and distributing videos on experimental procedures, 2) recruiting beta-testing labs, 3) hosting demo sessions at conferences, and 4) collaborating with industry partners. Female and underrepresented minority students will participate extensively in the proposed research projects.

The proposed PFM takes advantage of unique features offered by both plasmonics (i.e., the interaction between light and nanomaterials) and microfluidics. It improves the sensitivity of traditional nanoaperture-based sensors by 20-120 times. In addition to improved sensitivity, the proposed PFM technique provides more precise fluidic control, minimizes consumption of samples and reagents, and reduces equipment costs. This project will improve understanding on the interactions of light, fluid, and molecules at the micro/nano scale, contributing to the emerging field of plasmofluidics. The proposed PFM-based single-molecule studies on the T4 replisome will also improve understanding of the DNA replication process, which will not only elucidate fundamental processes of biology and biochemistry but also shed light on the therapeutics of many diseases, such as cancer and infectious diseases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we are developing an integrated plasmofluidic microscopy whose purpose is to conduct high-throughput, high-sensitivity single-molecule studies in a simple, compact, cost-effective, user-friendly format.  The proposed research will benefit the following biological research community: DNA replication and regulation, enzymology, cell membrane biology, and drug discovery. The outcome of this project includes:

  1. Successfully demonstrate acoustic modulation of surface plasmon resonance in microfluidic systems
  2. Successfully demonstrate label-free measurements of reaction kinetics using a droplet-based optofluidic device
  3. Successfully enrich nanoparticles via microfluidics
  4. Successfully demonstrate acoustic separation of nanoparticles in continuous flow
  5. Successfully demonstrate acoustofluidic waveguides for localized control of acoustic wavefront in microfluidics
  6. Successfully demonstrate  rotational manipulation of single cells and organisms using acoustic waves
  7. Successfully demonstrate 3D manipulation of single cells using surface acoustic waves
  8. Successfully demonstrate the ability to probe cell deformability via acoustically actuated bubbles
  9. Successfully conduct experimental and numerical studies on standing surface acoustic wave microfluidics
  10. Successfully demonstrate reusable acoustic tweezers for disposable devices
  11. Successfully demonstrate high-throughput acoustic cell sorters
  12. Successfully demonstrate acoustic separation of circulating tumor cells
  13. Successfully demonstrate the ability to control cell-cell interactions using surface acoustic waves
  14. Successfully demonstrate acoustic actuation of bioinspired microswimmers
  15. Successfully demonstrate mixing high-viscosity fluids via acoustically driven bubbles
  16. Successfully demonstrate acoustofluidic coating of particles and cells
  17. Successfully demonstrate high-throughput acoustic separation of platelets from whole blood
  18. Successfully demonstrate on-chip production of size-controllable liquid metal microdroplets using acoustic waves
  19. Successfully demonstrate acoustofluidic actuation of in situ fabricated microrotors
  20. Successfully demonstrate rapid formation of size-controllable multicellular spheroids via 3D acoustic tweezers
  21. Successfully demonstrate acoustofluidic devices controlled by cell phones
  22. Successfully demonstrate acoustic actuation of in situ fabricated artificial cilia
